heading: GERMAN REALISM
article_text: GERMAN  REALISM   "Winter,"  by  P.  Griese.  Translated  from  tbo  German  by.Adler  Hobman-  Published  by  Long  mans,-  London,  >   A  book  .as  powerful  as  it,is  gloomy  has  been  written  by  a  German  school*  master  who..has  found  his  metier  as  a  novelist,  Griese.  is  a  realist,  with  vivid  »pen  which  is  used  with  the  -  sparing  economy  of  the  artist  and  the  imagina  tion  of  the  poet.  Ilis  picture  of  an  obscure  and.isolated  farming  village  through  a  summer  of  drought  followed  by  an  early  winter  of  phenomenal  severity  will  not  readily  fade  from  the  'mind  of  those  who  absorb  his  pene  trating  chapters.  The  people  upon  whom  this  natural  affliction  is  visited  arc  purely  of  the  soilt  simple,  superstiti  ous,  self-centred,  almost  primitive  >in  their'  loves  and  •  hates.  •  The  stark  tragedy  of  that  awful  winter  which  left  the  farms  desolate  and  deserted  Is  matched  by  the  grimness  of  the  per  sonal  histories  unfolded.  Men  and  women  alike  have  the  stolidness  com-?  mon.  to  the  uneducated  and  specially  characteristic'  of  the  German  rustic,  and  from  this  quality  the  author  has  weaved  material  that  has  all  the  elements  of  social  drama.  The  hero  Jona  is  the  illegitimate  offspring  of  a  farmer's  daughter  and  an  .  alien  labourer  who  had  been  turned  from  the  farm-  when  his  attentions  to  .the  girl  became  apparent.  Jona  has  all  the  in  articulateness  .of  the  countryman  and  withstands  every  effort  to  induce  him  to  set  about  getting  a  wife.  Clearly  he  likes  Grita,  a  neighbouring  farmer's  daughter,  but  hesitates  to  speak,  and  a  less  unwilling  wooer  in  his  cups  forces  his  attentions  on  her  with  a  crudity  which  leaves  Grita  in  her  unr  sophisticated  simplicity  with  no  alter  native  but  to  marry"  the  man.  But  she  determined  to  be  wife  .  only  in  name  and  a  grim  scene  on  her  wedding,  night  is  only  averted  by  the  worse  tragedy  of  the  discovery  that  a  wronged  younger  sister  has  killed  herself  under  stress  of  taunts  at  the  wedding  supper  table.  Grita  and  her  Thord  in  their  estranged  relations  presents  a  "strange  commentary  on  village  heroics,  -and  the  tense  situation  is  ended  by  Jona  fighting  him  to  the  death.  Out  of  the  village  in  which  relentness  snow  storms  had  wrought  despair  and  star  vation  the  victor  and  Grita  pass  "into  some  shadowy  prospect  of  a  happier  future.  The  story  is  a  masterpiece  .of  fiction  and  carries  the  commendation  of  having  won  two  literary  prizes.  •
snippet: "Winter," by F. Griese. Translated from the German by Adler Hobman Published by Longmans, London. A book as powerful as it is gloomy

heading: GERMAN REPARATIONS
article_text: GERMAN  REPARATIONS   What  should  Germany  pay?  In  theory,  the  whole  cost  of  the  war  which  she  provoked.  But  the  bitter  truth  was  long  ago  recognised—first  by  Britain  and  last  of  all  by  exasper  ated  France—that  neither  Germany  nor  anyone  else  could  possibly  foot  the  whole  bllL  Moral  obligation  had  to  give  way  to  potential  fact,  and  the  question  became  not  what  "should'  but  what  "can"  Germany  pay?  That   matter  was  closely  studied  through  long  years,  averaging  and  calculatin;  on  a  basis  entirely  business-like,  ant'  fixed  amounts  were  determined,  fai  below  the  fair  but  touching  only  the  possible.  No  one  expected  the  Germans  to  welcome  this  minimum,  but  at  least  it  was  thought  that  they  would  feel  that  they  had  done  pretty  well  in  comparison  .with  what  might  have  been  insisted  on  (and  what  they  themselves  would  have  exacted,  if  victorious,  from  others).  Acceptance  of  the  Inevitable  should  surely  have  been  their  proper  course.  Instead  of  this,  however,  we  find  ourselves  face  to  face  with  new  demands  for  further  remissions.  An  Insidious  campaign  'in  forma  pauperis"  has  been  steadily  afoot  Against-this,  the  French  have  unceasingly  .protested,  though  in  England  a  certain  degree  of  sympathy  has  at  times  been  mildly  shown.  British  opinion,  however,  has  now  been  considerably  stiffened  by  the  Parker  Gilbert  report  That  document,  apart  altogether  from  its  highly  convincing  business  side,  merely  puts  into  words  the  justifiable  conviction  of  the  average  Briton,  who,  not  at  all  disposed  to  kick  even  the  most  ruthless  enemy  when  down,.  Is  nevertheless  quite  tinable  .to  see  why  the  losers  of  a  wanton  and  deliberate  war  should  suffer  from  its  effects  In  a  less  degree  than  those  who  ltchleTed  a  defensive  victory.  Forthatwas  all  that  the  Allies  gained  br,could  gain  —  successful  resistance,to  ^threatened  destruction.:  In  gaining:  tt^toiey';«^p)£nitned  themselves,  nonejnoreso  than  Britain.  And  It  certainly  the  TOrr  Climaxof  unreason  that  reparations  (there  Is  no  question  ol  ^nflemnitles)  which  have  already  bpen^ifeed  flown  to  tar  betow  &e  st&3ard  i>f  :«hat  would  have  been  :  righ^i^  jMtlce  should  t>e  the  iBeonans  .  gome-   what  inconvenient  All  tiie  evidence  suggests  that  Britain  is  even  yet  bear  ing  heavier  burdens  than  they,  having  lost  some  of  her  markets  even  to  the  Germans  themselves.  At  present:  most  of  Britain's  sympathy  and  concern  are  sorely  needed  for  lier  own  family,  and  -what  there  is  over  and  to  spare  may  well  be  extended  rather  to  Germany's  victims  than  to  Germany.  This  is  cold  justice,  not  hot  vindictiveness.  Britain  does  not  bear  ill-will.  Hp  to  almost  the  outbreak  of  the  war,  Germany  had  her  friendship,  for  the  mass  of  our  "people  disregarded  all  warning.  That  friend  ship  she  deliberately  destroyed  though  even  already,  after  all  that  has  happened,  there  arc  signs  that  she  may  gradually  recover  it  if  she  conducts  herself  with  ordinary  sense.  She  won  back  a  certain  amount  of  respect  from  the  discerning  by  her  refusal  tc  go  Bolshevik  at  a  time  when  temptation  pointed  to  that  course  as  s  possible  escape  from  all  debts  whatever.  Having  resisted  that,  her  pose  of  mendicancy  comes  with  all  the  poorer  spirit.  Nor  •will  it  be  accept  ed.  The  mere  proposal  has  united  the  Allies  more  closely  again,  drawn  Britain  nearer  to  the  French  point  "of  vie.  Germany  has  hitherto  been  remarkably  lucky,  not  through  deserv   ings  but  by  force  of  circumstances  She  ought  to  recognise  that,  and  not  to  lodge  appeals  which  border  very  closely  on  presumption.

heading: German Reparations
article_text: German  Reparations   The  flfth  and  most  important  year  for  the  payment  of  reparation?  under  the  Dawes  plan  began  on  September  1.  The  annuity  for  1028-9  amounts  to  £125,000,  000,  and  constitutes  the  so-called  "stand-  ard"  payment.  It  represents  an  increase  of  £37,500,000  over  the  fourth  annuity  The  whole  of  this  increase  has  to.bo  ob-  tained  from  the  German  Budget,  the  con-  tribution  of  which  rises  from  £25,000,000  to  £62,500,000.  The  transport  tax  will  again  contribute  £14,500,000,  the  German  railway  bonds  £33,000,000,  and  the  Ger-  man  industrial  debentures  £15,000,000  In  future  the  standard  annuity  Is  subject  ti  modifications  only  through  the  applica-  tion  of  the  index  of  prosperity,  which  may  serve  to  Increase  It,  or  It  may  be  in-  creased  or  decreased  on  account  of  changes  In  the  general  purchasing  power  of  gold.  The  German  Budget  contribu-  tions  nre  taken  from  the  controlled  re-  venues  (i.e..  Customs,  tobacco,  sugar,  beer  and  spirits  monopoly),  by  the  Com-  missioner  of  Controlled  Revenues  as  re-  ceived  and  aro  paid  over  monthly  to  tho  Agent-General,  payments  being  mnde  about  the  fifth  of  the  month;  but  in  view  of  the  larger  nmounts  to  be  paid  in  the  fifth  year  it  has  been  arranged  that  the  payments  in  1928-9  shall  be  mado  on   |  three  occasions  during  each  month  so  as   .  to  avoid  an  undue  tying  up  oí  funds,  .

heading: German Census.
article_text: German  Census.  ,  —   The  provisional  results  of  the  census  of  June  16  show  that  the  population  of  Germany  is  62,500,000,  or  about  the  same  as  in  1908,  as  compared  with  68,000,000  at  the  outbreak  of  the  war.  It  is  estimated  that  Germany  lost  7,000,000  by  the  cession  of  territories  under  the  Peace  Treaty,  2,750,000  from  deaths  in  wartime,  and  2,500,000  by  the  decrease  of  the  birthrate  in  wartime;  therefore,  but  for  tho  war  the  population  would  have  been  75,000,000.  Nevertheless,  the  population  has  increased  3,333,000  as  compared  with  1919,  and  Berlin  is  the  second  largest  city  in  Europe,  with  a  population  of  3,900,000.

heading: GERMAN INDUSTRY.
article_text: GERIAN  INDUSTRY.  Sir  Philip  Gibbs  gives  a  remarkable  account  of  the  new  spirit  and  the  re  newal  of  industry  in  Germany.  "Her  people  are  working  harder  than  any  others,  at  lower  wages,  and  with  more  efficient  organisation.  They  have  been  braced  by  defeat,  whereas  the  victor  nations,  and  above  all  Great  Britain,  have  been  slackened  by  victory,"  he  writes  in  the  "Review  of  Reviews."  The  Change  in  the  People.  "When  I  went  first  into  Germany  after  the  armistice  the  people  seemed  stupefied  by  what  had  befallen  them.  All  their  faith  had  been  shattered  by  the  downfall  of  their  armies,  and  they  were  afraid  of  revolution,  and  hopeless.  ly  uncertain  of  the  future.  Many  of  them,  ;especially  the  women  and  chil  dren,  were  still  suffering  from  the  effects'  of  long  under-feeding,  ,prices  of  food,  clothing,  and  other  necessities  of  life  were  above  the  reach  of  working  folk,  demobilised  soldiers  were  not  yet  assimilated  into  civil  life.  and  the  spirit  of  the  people  was  dejected  and  de  spairing.  "Now,  in  Berlin  the  general'  appear  ance  of  the  people  is  not  miserable  but  cheerful,  not  dejected  but  alert  and  con  fident.  One  does  not  see  crowds  of  listless  unemployed  men  hanging  about  labour  exchanges  or  rattling  collecting  boxes  in  the  faces  of  the  passers-by.  One  sees  crowds  of  men  stepping  out  briskly,  obviously  employed,  well-dressed,  well-fed,  keen"  on  their  jobs,  doing  good  business.  Krupp's  5s.  Day.  "The  German  working  man  in  Krupp's  factories  and  others,  is  paid  60  marks  a  day.  At  the  old  value  of  the  mark  that  would  be  £3.  At  the  present  value,  inside  Germany  itself,  I  reckon  it  as  five  shillings.  "For  an  eight-hour  day  it  works  out  at  74d.  an  houi  compared  with  1s.  9d.  to  2s.  6d.  an  hour  of  the  mechanic  in  \Great  Britain.  "The  German  working  man  on  60  marks  a.  day  gets  almost  enough  to  eat  (never  enough  meat),  almost  enough  to  support  a  wife  and  small  family,  almost  enough  to  make  himself  satisfied'  with  his  job.  By  strict  attention  to  economy,  he  can  squeeze  out  a  few  marks  for  the  simple  pleasures  of  his  leisure  hours,  which  consist  mostly  in  light  beer  and  light  music  in  some  public  garden  or  beer-hall.  "The  professional  classes,  and  the  clerical  classes  (city  clerks,  typists,  etc.)  are  not  so  well  off  relatively  as  the  mechanics'  and  labourers.  Whereas  the  cost  of  living  has  increased  from  eight  to  10  times,  the  salaries  of  professors,  teachers,  civil  .servants,  and  others  have  only  risen  from  4  to  6  times.  It  is  they  who  are  most  pinched  'and  reduced  to  desperate  straits  in  order  to  'keep  up  appear  ances.  .  A  New  Industrial  Organisation.  "Now,  upon  the  great  mass  of  cheap  labour  German  capitalists  are  building  up  a  new  and  intensive  sytem  .of  indus  trial  organisation,  beyond  anything  the  world  has  previously  seen  in  efficiency  and  driving  power.  Hugo  Stinnes,and  his'great  Trust,  controlling  a  vast  mo  nopoly  of  coal,  iron  and  steel,  of  whom  there  has  been  much  talk,  because  he  re  presents  most  powerfully  'this  new  phase  of  German  energy,  is  only  one  of  a  score  of  other  magnates  who  prac  tically  control  the  whole  industrial  life  of  .Germany,  and  are  the  real  rulers  of.  the  State.  "Their  method  is  what  is  described  as  the  creation  of  'vertical'  trusts.  That  is  to  say,  by  a  combination  and  pool  ing  of  many  companies  in  possession  of  raw  material  and  industrial  plant  they  build  up  an  immense  production  .of  manu  factured  articles  which  have  that  raw  material  as  their  basis.  Krupp's  Peaceful  Output.  "Thus  the  great  munition  works  of  Krupp,  entirely  engaged  in,  the  produc  tion  of  guns  and  armaments  during  the  war  'bon  a  colossal  scale,  read  the  lesson  of  defeat,  and  within  a  few  months  after  the  Armistice,  adapted  their  plant  and  their  organising  genius  in  a  marvellous  way  to  the  requirements  of  peace.  They  are  now  making  engines  and  machinery  of  all  kinds,  agricultural  implements,  cash  registers,  safety  razors,  and  any  kind  of  article  in  iron  and  steel  for  which  there  is  a  world  market.  The  General  Electric  Company  is  also  de  veloping  its  energy  with  gigantic  strides,  reaching  out  to  'neutral'  countries  and  absorbing  many  industrial  concerns  of  which  the  basis  of  activity  is  coal  and  iron  and  electrical  power,  in  Austria,  Hungary,  and  other  countries..  "These  great  Trusts,  are  already  cap  turing  the  world's  markets,  and  have  already  succeeded  in  recovering  some  of  the  pre-war.  prosperity  of  German  trade-which  is  almost  a  miracle  con  sidering  the  ruin  of  the  German  economic  system  by  the  exhaustion  of  a  bloody  and  unsuccessful  war,  the  loss  of  colonies,  shipping,  and  foreign  pro  perty,  the  loss  of  man  power,  and  the  deterioration  of  machinery,  railways,  and  rolling  stock.  Imports  Falling  Off.  '¶masing  as  all  this  is,  however,  one  must  not  exaggerate  the  actual  results.  Germany  is  not  rolling  in  wealth,  as  some  observers  have  reported.  Apart  alto  gether  from  her  international  debts  leaving  on  one  side  altogether  the  gigantic  payments  of  the  indemnities  which  she  has  undertaken-her  industry  and  com  merce  are  about  two-thirds  normal  com  pared  with  the  pre-war  standard.  Her  imports  of  cotton  amount  to  nearly  half  of  thcse  in  1913.  Her  ioal  output  during  the  first  four  months  of  this  year  was  44,500,000  tons  compared  with  57,000,000  toxas  in  the  same  period  of  1913.  "Half  the  amount  of  pre-war  tonnage  (largely  under  foreign  flags)  is  now  coming  into  the  port  of  Iamburg.   If  They  Pay!  "All  this  is  a  sign  of  industrial  and  conmmunercial  recovery,  astoundmg  as  a  proof  of  cnergy,  industry,  and  organised  efficiency,  after  the  shock  of  national  de  feat.  But  those  German  people  who  have  put  up  such  a  tremendous  fight  for  their  old  place  in  the  world  are  now  confronted  with  the  necessity  of  paying  indemnities  to  the  victor  nations  which  will  test  their  power  of  recovery  to  the  uttermost  and  demand  new  and  unpre  cedented  efforts.  It  is  not  going  to  be  easy  for  them  to  pay.  If  they  suc  ceel,  it  will  be  the  greatest  industrial  adventure  ever  undertaken  by  any  people  in  the  world.  To  succeed  they  must  in  crease  their  volume  of  exports  by  at  least  fotir  times,  which  would  be  an  achievement  unrivalled  in  the  industrial  history  of  the  world.  Con  they  do  that.  and  if  they  do  what  will  be  the  effect  upon  other  nations?  "It  has  already  been  asked  by  Mr.  Reginald  McKenna.  What  will  happen  to  British  trade  if  Germany  pays  her  indemnities  in  the  only  way  possible  by  an  immense  increase  of  exports?  The  very  fulfilment  of  her  pledges  will  ruin  the  countries  receiving  payment  by  the  destruction  of  their  own  export  trade.  .o  we  reach  the  monstrous  para  dox  that  in  shouting  *Make  Germany  pay!'  we  were  insisting  upon  our  own  ruin.  The  only  aure  for  the  present  sickness  of  world  trade  is  to  return  to  normal  canditions  of  imports  balancing  exports,  and  of  a  free  and  natural  flow  of  trade.  "Condensing  very  briefly  the  results  of  my  visit  to  Berlin,  it  will  be  seen  that  in  my  opinion  Germany  will  make  a  serious  endeavour  to  fulfil  her  pledges,  and  is  in  a  fair  way  (if  she  retains  the  resources  of  ,her  raw  material  in  Upper  Silesia  and  elsewhere)  to  capture  the  industrial  supreieny  of  Europe."

heading: GERMAN WOOLS.
article_text: GERMAN  WOOLS.   "During  the  last  few  weeks  several  Bradford  houses  have  received  offers  of  fair-sized  parcels  of  "German-grown"  wool  in  the  grease,  and  this  unusual  develop-  ment  has  occasioned  some  comment,"  re-  marks  the  "Wool  Record  and  Textile  World"  of  July  24.  "At  one  time,  of  course,  large  weight«  of  German  wool  were  imported,  but  for  many  years  past  the  comparatively  small  quantity  grown  in  Germany  has  been  disposed  of  in  that  country.  In  1824  we  imported  44,000  bales  of  German  merino  wool  and  25.000  bales  from  Spain,  those  countries  being  [  the  chief  sources  of  supply.  The  relative  !  importance  of  the  then  wool-exporting  !  countries  may  be  gathered  from  the  fact  .  that,  in  the  same  year,  we  imported  ?  from  Sydney  972  bales,  from  Tasmania  '  619  bales,  and  from  the  Gape  43  bales.  A  recent  estimnte  of  the  number  of  sheep  in  Germany  gives  the  total  at  just  over  Si  millions,  so  that  it  is  obvious  that  the  amount  of  wool  available  is  very  small.  The  significant  thing  is  that  Ger   man.  (firms  are  finding  the  financial  strin-  gency  so  acute  that  they  are  offering  their  "domestic  wools  in  a  market  where  there  is  some  prospect  of  realising  sterling,  the  natural  inference  being  that  their  usual  customers  at  home  arc  un-  able  to  pay  cash."

heading: GERMAN NAVY
article_text: GERMAN  NAVY   President  Von  Hindenburg  last  week  reviewed  the  first  German  naval  parade  since  the  war.  The  whole  fleet,  except  ships  on  service,  took  part.  It  consisted  of  four  armored  battleships,  three  cruisers,  the  first  and  second  torpedo  flotillas,  and  three  new  de-  stroyers.  There  were  no  seaplanes  or  submarines,  the  construction  of  these  being  forbidden  by  the  Treaty  of  Ver-  sailles.  The  same  manoeuvres  were  carried  out  as  at  the  battle  of  Jutland.

heading: GERMAN POLITICS.
article_text: GERMAN  POLITICS.   THE  NEW  CABINET.  Following  the  recent  election,  the  new  Prjme  Minister  (Hermann  Mueller)  selected  a  new  Cabinet.  Seated  —  Dr.  Erich  Koch-Weser,  Minister  of  Justice;  Herr  Hermann  Muller,  Premier;  General  Groener,  Minister  of  Defence;  Herr  Wissel,  Minister  of  Labor.  Standing  —  Herr  Hermann  Dietrich,  Minister  of  Food  Supply;  Dr.  Hilferding,  Minister  of  Finance;  Dr.  Ernst  Curtius,  Minister  of  National  Economy;  Dr.  Karl  Severing,  Minister  of  the  Interior;  Herr  von  Guerard,  Minister  of  Occupied  Territories,  and  Dr.  Schaetzel,  Minister  of  Communications.

heading: GERMAN REVOLUTION.
article_text: GERMAN  REVOLUTION.  Official  circles  in  London  consider  there  Is  now  a  good  prospect  of  order  being  completely  restored  in  Germany.  The  British  diplomatic  representative  congratulated  the  Constitutional  Government  on  Dr.  Kapp's  overthrow.  He  warned  the  Government  that  the  Allies  would  only  supply  foodstuffs  provided  order  prevailed  in  the  country.  The  Parts  "Matin"  learns  that  Admiral  Evers  has  been  appointed  Governor  of  Keil.  The  disarming  of  the  troops  there  continues.  The  workers  in  Leipzig,  where  fighting  has  been  resumed,  shot  down  an  aeroplane.  Seven  hundred  people  wore  killed  in  Dortmund,  and  400  around  Essen.  Correspondents  estimate  that  the  number  of  killed  in  Germany  during  the  week  exceeds  2000  One  thing  the  revolution  has  achieved  has  been  the  increase  of  the  German  people's  hatred  of  millitarlsm,  which  will  result  In  a  stronger  democratic  control  of  the  army.  The  lynching  of  20  officers  of  the  Baltic  Contingent  it  a  Schoneberg  suburb  was  due  to  their  arrogant  attitude  causing  the  mob  to  pull  them  from  a  motor  lorry,  one  by  one,  and  beat  and  kick  them  to  death.

heading: GERMAN PRESIDENCY.
article_text: GERMAN  PRESIDENCY.  The  election  of  Marshal  Von  RLin  dsburg  to  the  German  Prelsidency  will  occasion  a  good  deal  of  misgiving  in  Europe,  and  particularly  In  France,  where  every  action  of  Germany  is  re  garded  with  the  gravest  suspicion.  It  is  hardly  likely,  of  cource,  that  there  will  be  any  immediate  change  of  Gcr.  man  Dolicy.  Even  the  supporters  of  the  now  President,  Jubilant  as  they  must  be,  would  not  dare  to  take  the  jisk  of  provoking  civil  war.  At  the  same  time  the  victory  of  HiIndenburg,  who  is  tihe  figurehead  of  the  Monarchists,  is  sug  gestive  of  the  growing  strength  of  that  element  which  would  turn  thle  military  defeat  of  the  Great  War  Into  a  diplo  matic  success,  or  at  least  a  draw  with  out  penalties.  There  was  a  time  when  the  aged  marshal's  name  was  one  to  conjure  with.,  iHe  was  the  Idol  of  a  deluded  people,  but  when  the  "im  pregnable"  imne  which  bore  his  name  was  broken,  when  the  Australlans  participated  in  the  smashing  blow  that  crumpled  up  his  armies,  ficktle  fame  deserted  him.  Since  then  he  Ilas  tasted  the  sorrows  as  well  as  the  sweets  of  public  eminence.  A  hero  and  a  butt,  a  national  saviour  and  a  na   tional  scapegoat,  a  great  soldier  to  whom  a  war  fired  people  paid  bound  less  homage,.  and  a  reputed  failure  bowed  down  beneath  popular  derision,  all  these  vagaries  Von  Hindenburg  has  experienced:  and  now  he  has  emerged  from  obsburity  into  triumph.  He  has  becomen  the  leader  of  tile  German  na  tion  with.  power  to  mould  its  progress  to  his  will.  Through  all  the  conflict  of  opinion  that  filters  through  the  calbles  it  is  difficult  to  gauge  with  any  degree  of  accuracy  the  trend  of  th'ought  in  Ger  many.  Tile  statements  the  new  PrCs  dent  has  m'ale  frops  time  to  tintme  have  in  them  the  elements  of  confu  sion;  but  it  seems  reasonably  certain  that  the  nation  as  a  whole  is  by  no  means  irrevocably  coninitted  to'  tile  republican  form  of  government.  Nor  is  there  .any  sound  ground  for  believing  that  .the  nation  Is  prepared  tio  accept  the  consequences  of  the  d~feat  of  her  reckless  bid  for  world  power.  It  has  been  well  sald  thatthere  is  no  sign  of  'disarmament  of  the  intellect  in  Ger  many,"  and  the  Allied  Military  Mis  sion  has  discovered  disturbing  signs  of  purposeful  evasion  of  treaty  obliga  tions.  The  same  spirit  has  been  en  countered  in  other  directions.  The  schemes  of  successive  governments  to  outwit  theAllies  and  hscape  financial  burdens  ruined  tile  countr.y's  .cur  rency'and  shattered  its  credit.  Sonme  months  ago  we  pointed  out  that  *  the  trouble  seems  to  be  the  persistence  of  tile  Prusslan  military  caste,  backed  by  the  war  profiteers  and  imperiallaistic  intellectuals.  German  democracy  is  being  trampled  upon  by  thle  wcr  lords,  and  there  is  little  prospect  of  real  peace  until  the  yoke  of  the  Juinkers  has  been  removed  front  their  necks.  There  is  dome  consolation.  in  the  knowledge  that  the  Republican  vote  is  still  a  force  to  be  reckoned  with  in  tile  constituencieo.  In  tfact  some  of  tihe  election  figures  which  have  just  been  published  suggest  that  there  are  more  Republicans  thaAl  Monarchists.  and  whether  their  preference  for  Dr.  Marx  indicated  a  belief  that  the  Replublican  form  of  gpvernment  was  the  ideal,  or  merely  the  best  expedient  for  mollify  ing  publlec  opinion  in  othler  countries,  tile  result  is  much  thle  same.  Von  -in  denburg  cannot  afford  to  isgnore  that  feeling  entirely. heading: [?] [?] GERMAN
article_text: WEDDING   LUCKIE—FREEMAN.   The  singing  of  "O,  Perfect  Love,"  by  St.  Augustine's  Church  of  England  choir,  heralded  the  arrival  of  Miss  Ag-  nes  Freeman  on  Tuesday  evening  last  for  her  marriage  to  Mr.  John  F.  W.  Luckie,  of  Booleroo,  N.S.W.,  and  form-  erly  of  Inverell.  The  bride  is  the  youngest  daughter  of  Mrs.  A.  Free-   man,  of  Inverell,  and  the  late  Mr.  A.  de  M.  Freeman,  and  the  bridegroom  is  the  only  son  of  Mr.  and  Mrs.  W.  Luckie,  of  Mendooran.  Rev.  E.  H.  Stammer  officiated  and  Miss  Patt  pre-  sided  at  the  organ.  A  veil  of  Brussels  lace,  over  a  beau-  tifully  cut  gown  of  silver  tinsel  satin,  was  worn  by  the  bride,  who  looked  radiant  on  entering  the  church,  accompanied  by  her  brother-in-law,  Mr.  E.  Hargrave,  who  subsequently  gave  her  away.  The  bride  carried  a  bouquet  of  blue  lillies  and  cornflowers,  tied  with  silver  streamers.  Miss  Mona  Delbridge  was  bridesmaid   and  wore  a  frock  of  blue  embossed  satin,  which  was  made  with  chiffon  shoulder  drapes  falling  to  the  hemline.  She  wore  a  head-dress  of  blue  tulle,  with  a  coronet  of  cream  roses,  and  carried  a  bouquet  of  cream  roses  tied  with  blue  streamers.  Mr.  A.  D.  Freeman,  brother  of  the  bride,  attended  to  the  duties  of  best  man.  The  church  was  beautifully  decorated  with  roses  and  snapdragons,  and  was  the  artistic  work  of  the  brides  many  girl  friends,  who  also  attended  to  the  decorations  in  the  Masonic  hall,  where  the  reception  was  later  held.  Here  the  color  scheme  was  carried  out  in  blue  and  white,  a  large  horse-shoe  of  white  and  silver  predominating  at  the  back  or  the  bridal  table,  presenting  a  picturesque  setting  for  the  occasion.  Large  bowls  of  sweet-peas,  roses,  and   aquelegias  graced  the  tables,  whilst  the  beautifully-decorated  two-decker  cake  held  pride  of  place.  About  one  hundred  guests  were  re-  ceived  by  Mrs.  Freeman,  who  chose  a  lovely  gown  of  black  velvet  with  black  toque,  and  carried  a  posy  of  Tal-  isman  roses.  Mrs.  E.  Hargrave  as-  sisted,  wearing  a  gown  of  blue  georget-  te.  Harding's  orchestra  was  in  at-  tendance  and  rendered  numbers  ap-  propriate  to  the  occasion,  and  later  when  the  guests  indulged  in  dancing.  When  leaving  for  the  honeymoon,  which  is  being  spent  motoring  on  the  South  Coast,  the  bride  chose  a  smart  tailored  costume,  with  navy  accessor-  ies.  The  young  couple,  whose  future  home   will  be  at  Booleroo,  N.S.W.,  were  the  recipients  of  a  beautiful  array  of  gifts,  which  were  displayed  on  tables  in  the  hall,  and  received  much  favourable  comment  from  the  guests.

article_text: AUSTRALIANS  AND  WAR   German  Opinion   The  London  "Daily  Herald,"  in  a  leading  article,  comments  on  a  state-  ment  by  a  contributor  to  Field-marshal  Goering's  newspaper,  the  "National  Aeitung,"  that  the  British  Empire   would  not  hold  together  in  time  of  war,  and  that  Australia  would  keep  out  of  the  firing  line.  The  "Daily  Herald"  quotes  the  as-  surance  of  the  Australian  Prime  Min-  ister.  Mr.  Menzies,  (that  "Australia  will  be  there."  "Such  false  judgments  as  those  of  the  "National  Zeitung"  are  made  be-  cause  their  originators  do  not  realise  that  brothers  and  sisters  need  not  make  pacts  to  ensure  that  they  belong  to  the  same  family,"  it  adds.

heading: GERMAN CARS FOR GERMAN PRESTIGE
article_text: GERMAN  CARS  FOR  GERMAN  PRESTIGE   Before  an  80  000  cheering  crowd  of  Britishers  a  German  car  won  the  Donington  Grand  Pr'x  race  again.  Tazio  Nuvolari,  the  48  year-old  Ital  ian  driver,  was  at  the  wheel  of  the  winning  car.   The  wonderful  speed  spectacle  of  the  German  cars  has  spoiled  the  interest  oi  the  public  in  other  racing  events  in  Brit  ain,  in  which  only  British  cars  partici  pate.  Last  year  the  Germans  arrived,  with  their  200  m.p.h.  cars  and  won  the  first  four  places  in  the  Grand  Prix  race.  Since  then  gates  at  British  motor  races  have  dropped  alarmingly.  The  German  Government  spends  from  £50.000  to  £100,000  annually  on  their  cars.  British  manufacturers  feel  that  they  cannot  afford  to  spend  such  huge  amounts.  Unless  the  British  Government  is  pre  pared  to  follow  the  example  of  the  NaxI  Government  the  visiting  German  cars  will  win  every  time.  The  German  ears  are  not  built  for  public  ues,  but  solely  for  increasing  German  prestige.  /

heading: GERMAN AMBITIONS. Czech-German Animosity.
article_text: :  GERMAN  AMBITIONS.   Czech-German  Animosity.   (Contributed  by  the  Longue  of  ,  ('■  ’  Nations  Union).1   '  The  latter  half  of  October  10-3«  wna  !   marked  by  a  revival  of  bitter  anti  Czech  propaganda  In  the  German  Press,  The  outbreak  lmd  ns  a  pre  text  a’clash  with  the  Czech  police  and   members.of  the  Sudetan  Doutch  party  nt  Toplltz-Schonau,  In  Czechoslovakia.  Knrl  Frank,  deputy  leader  of  the  party  and  others,  came  in^conflict-.wlth  ..the  ‘police,  as^  they  were  making  way  for  him  and  other  leaders  to  get  to  their  motor’cars  after  having  addressed’a  political  meeting  that  had  been  for  bidden  by  the  police.  The  incident  followed  the  arrest,  a  few  weeks  earl  ier,  of  another  prominent  member  of  tho'party,  Hans  Rutha,  on  non  political  charges  concerning  public   moralB.   .  The  Sudeten  .  Doutch  comprise  the  majority  of  the  large  Germun  minority  in  Czechoslovakia.  Unlike  the  mod  erate  -  minority  of  Germans,  in  that  country,  the  Sudeten  Doutsch  refuses  to  co'-operato  with  the  Czech  Govern  ment.  •  They  are  Nazi  in  outlook,  and  favour  the  establishment  of  "MU  tel  Buropa”  under  the  influence  of  the  Tfhird  Reich.  As  an  outcome  of  the  Teplitz-Schonau  incident  their  leader  Konrad  Hcnlein,  in  a  letter  to  Presi  dent  Bones,  has  demanded  “autonomy"  for"  all  Gormans  living  in  Czechoslo  vakia,   The  German  Press  accused  the  Czech  police  of  “serious  excesses,’*  de  claring  that  “Sudetlc  Germun  patience  is  at  an  end.  The  ntmosphere  is  laden-with,  thunder,  and  a  single  spark  might'  be  '  suillclcnt  to,  turn  this  Incident  into  u^ftre  of  revolt."  V''The  National  Zelturig  of  Bsson  (Gen.  GoerJng's  paper)  declared  that  the  in  cident  was  an  Insult,  to  70,000,000  Germans.   It  turned  again  to  accusing  the   Czech  government  of  conspiracy  with  Soviet  Russia  against  Germany,  de  claring  that  dt  was  under  Russian  ■  patronage  that  the  Czechs  oxerclscd  their  ’barbarous"  rule.  The  Czech  Press,  without  regard  to  political  party,  strongly  condemned  the  activ  ities  of  the  Sudctic  Germans,  and  re  fused  to.  publish  Henloin's  letter  to  President  Benes,  -and  Herr  Henleln’s  paper,  in  which  Ills  letter  appeared,  was  confiscated.   Meanwhile,  Dr.  Mastny,  the  Czech  Ambassador,  made  an  oRlcial  protest  in  Berlin  agaiinst  the  attitude  of  the  German  press,  blit  the  German  Foreign  Minister  rebuffed  ’  the  protest'  as  misplaced.  \r  •  ‘   Tlie  real  significance  of  the  out  break  lies  deeper,  and  is  part  of  a  long-continued  effort  by  Germany  to  get  Czechoslovakia  to  break  off  treaty  connection  with  Soviet  Russia.  Ger  man  press  propaganda  to  this  end  has  continuously  alleged  the  presence  in  Czechoslovakia  of  Russian  aviators  and  military  officers,  and  the  erection  of  Soviet  military  aerodromes  on  Czech  territory,  ns  well  as  the  build  ing  of  a  strategic  railway  which  will  link  Czechoslovakia  directly  to  Russia  through  Roumania.   Behind,  this  again  lies  the  German  dream  ~of  “Mlttel  Buropa,”  In  which  nil  the  German-speaking  people  of  Central  13urope  are  to  be  united  into  one  ’‘Grenter  Germany,”  which  will   dominate  Central  and  'Eastern  Europe:  politically  and  economically.  Ger  many  thus  seeks  a  free  hand  In  East  ern  Europe,  and  feels  she  might  achieve  it  if  she  could  discredit  -Czechoslovakia  In  the  eyes  of  the  Western  .lSuropean  nations,  particu  larly  England.  It  is  significant,  therefore,  that  opinion  in  England  is  already  divided.  Thcrp  arc  thosq  who  would  defend  the  integrity  of  Czecho  slovakia  at  all  costs,.  and  those  who  would  readily  sacrifice  the  Czechs  if  they  thought  they  could  keep  war  from  Western  Europe.   At  the-  same  lime,  another  move  ment  Is  growing  in  Central  Europe  among  the  small  nations  who  fear  tlm  they  might  be  swallowed  up  by  Ger  many.  Relations  between  Czecho  slovakia,  Austria  and  Hungary  are  more  cordial  than  ever  before,  and  might  led  to  something  like  n  defen  sive  alliance. He  said  the  gathering  indicat  ed  the  unparalleled  unity  of  the  Ger  man  people,  and  added:  'We  shall  never  capitulate.  The  greater  our  distress,  the  greater  our  strength.' heading: GERMAN COURTESY.
article_text: GERMAN  COURTESY.   J\  U1UIOITSL  VVI1V  JtA.SL   from  a  holiday  in  Germany,  was  par  ticularly  impressed  by  the  courtesy  extended  to  him  throughout  his  tour.  One  thing  which  he  noticed  particu  larly  was  the  ready  assistance  forth  coming  from  passers-by,  particularly  in  larger  towns  and  cities.  On  more  than  one  occasion,  he  tells  us,  no  sooner  had  he  pulled  up  to  take  stock  of  his  surroundings  than  a  passer-by,  notic  ing  the  foreign  registration  of  the  car,  came  up  to  enquire  whether  he  could  be  of  any  assistance  to  guide  the  traveller  to  his  destination.  German  frontier  authorities  hand  the  visiting  motorist  a  booklet  giving  full  illu  strated  details  of  the  German  traffic  signs  and  a  list  of  the  principal  rules  of  the  road,  the  latter  being  printed  in  German,  French  and  English.

heading: GERMAN DEBTS.
article_text: GERMAN  DEBTS.   When  Germany,  a  month  ago,  placed  an  embargo  upon  the  import  of  wool,  amongst  other  raw  materials,  it  was  noted  here  that  this  situation  had  been  arrived  at  as  part  of  a  German  programme  to  bring  pressure  to  bear  upon  her  debtors  in  regard  to  the  payment  of  the  debts  owed  by  that  country  overseas.   For  some  two  years  now  Germany  has  not  been  paying  the  interest  upon  her  debts,  whilst  instalments  of  principal  long  ago  ceased.  A  crisis  has  now  been  reached  with  the  refusal  of  Germany,  through  the  mouth  of  Dr.  Schacht  (president  of  the  Reichsbank),  to  pay  interest  or  any  proportion  of  interest  upon  her  debts,  includ  ing  the  Dawes  and  Young  loans.  This  step  amounts  to  repudiation.  The  requests,  polite  enough  in  all  conscience,  of  the  British  and  French  Governments  for  further  information  on  the  situation,  are  declared  by  the  Nazi  organs  to  be.  'mere  bluff'  and  the  principal  Nazi  newspaper  states  that,  should  England  take  any  active  steps  against  Germany  in  regard  to  these  debts,  Germany  would  'retaliate  against  the  whole  British  Empire  which  sells  considerably  more  to  Germany  than  it  buys  from  her'.  'Whilst  it  may  be  true  that  Germany  buys  more  from  the  British  Empire  than  that  Empire  buys  from  her,  the  thought  might  occur  even  to  the  Nazi  intelligence  that  it  is  no  benefit  to  sell  to  a  country  which  does  not  pay.  It  is  better  to  be  without  the  business.  .  Ever  since  the  AVar  period,  German  national  finance  has  been  a  stumbling  block  to  Europe.  After  the  inflation  period  the  Dawes  loan  was  floated,  for  the  purpose  of  putting  Germany  upon  her  financial  feet  and  restoring  her  currency.  When  the  final  reparation  settlement  was  arrived  at,  the  Young  loan  was  floated  to  assist  in  that  settlement.  Germany  had  the  money  but  reparations  have  been  done  away  with.  At  every  turn  Germany  has  scored,  and  she  proposed  to  crown  her  victories  of  the  past  by  an  open  repudiation  of  her  international  obligations.  It  may  or  it  may  not  be  surprising  that  Nazi  finance  should  in  the  end  come  down  to  the  same  level  as  the  finance  of  the  Bolshevists,  to  whom  the  Nazi  spirit  is  alleged  to  be  so  opposed.  The  affair  may  prove  to  be  a  further  lesson,  and  it  may  be  hoped  a  lesson  which  will  sink  home,  to  those  who  for  so  long  have  argued  that  the  reconstruction  of  world  trade  can  only  be,  or  chiefly  be,  accomplished  by  the  financial  reconstruction  of  Europe.  Hun  dreds  of  millions  of  pounds  have  been  lent  to  the  countries  of  Central  Europe  for  reconstruction  purposes,  with  the  consequence  that,  with  one  exception  (Czechoslovakia),  they  are  all  to-day  as  bankrupt  as  they  ever  were.

heading: GERMAN SHIPPING.
article_text: GERMAN  SHIPPING.   Herr  Liiidermanii,  chairman  of  the  recent  Meeting  of  Share  holders  of  Deutsche  Lloyd,  re  viewing  conditions  during  the  past  year,  pointed  out  that  the  Company  had  lost  in  1933  no  less  than  2S,  000,000  Reichsmarks  net   on  exchange,  and  for  the  year  1934  would  lose  no  less  than  30,000,000  Reichsmarks.  In  other  respects,  however,  the  position  of  the  Company  had  improved.  It  had  been  able  to  withdraw,  with  out  further  loss,  from  the  finan  cial  entanglements  of  the  J.  Schroeder  Bank,  the  Nordwolle  (North  German  'Wool  Co.),  and  the  Municipal  Savings  Bank.  The  subsidiary  companies  are  all  'be-  ing-  placed  on  an  entirely  in  dependent  financial  basis,  with  satisfactory  results.  He  held  out  some  hope  of  improvement  in  the  comparatively  near  future,  indi-,  eating  that,  in  his  opinion,  the  world  was  thoroughly  sick  of  the  shipping  subsidy  business  and  nations  were,  beginning  to  recog  nise  the  disasters  which  it  pro  duced.  He  believed  that  within  a  short  time  an  International  Conference  would  be  held  to  con  sider  the  same.

heading: GERMAN AFFAIRS.
article_text: GERMAN  AFFAIRS.   On  Sunday  last  a  plebiscite  was  held  in  Germany,  by  which  it  was  supposedly  intended  that  the  people  of  Ger  -  many  should  Have  an  opportunity  of  expressing  their  opinion  of  the  amalgamation  of  the  two  offices  of  President  of  the  Republic  and  Chancellor  in  the  person  of  Adolf  Hitler,  the  Chancellor.   Previous  to  the  plebiscite  an  intensive  campaign  had  been  under  taken  by  microphone,  through  the  press,  by  every  sort  of  emotional  excitement,  to  ensure  that  the  result  of  the  voting  should  be  in  the  affirmative.  Considering  the  circumstances  of  government  in  Germany  to-day,  there  could  never  have  been  much  doubt  upon  this  point,  because  it  is  an  acknowledged  rule  of  Nazidom,  expressed  many  times  by  Herren  Hitler,  Goering  and  Goebbels,  that  there  can  be  no  opposition,  no  other  way  of  thinking  in  Germany  to  that  which  these  gentlemen  dictate.  The  result  of  the  plebiscite  was  in  the  affirmative,  and  it  has  even  been  described  as  a  victorious  result.  Upon  examining  the  figures,  however,  it  is  quite  clear  that  the  Nazi  Government  is  by  no  means  as  popular  as  might  appear  from  the  figures.  About  10  per  cent,  of  the  population  had  the  courage  to  vote  'No,'  whilst  almost  as  many  again  either  spoilt  their  ballot  papers  or  did  not  vote  at  all.  It  is  to  be  assumed  that  those  who  spoilt  their  papers  and  did  not  vote  were  definitely  opposed  to  the  present  regime  but  had  not  got  the  courage  to  say  so.  After  all,  the  present  circumstances  of  Germany  are  particularly  unhappy.  The  country  is  on  the  verge  of  bankruptcy;  the  restric  tions  upon  food,  clothing  and  raw  materials  are  reminiscent  of  war  time  measures:  the  Roman  Catholic  Church  is  deeply  dissatisfied,  and  the  Protestant  Church  not  less  so  ;  the  great  Industrialists  view  with  horror  the  swing  of  Nazi  economic  doctrine  towards  Com  munism  ;  even  in  the  ranks  of  Hitlerdom  there  is  certainly  great  unrest.  Foreign  observers  in  the  country  regard  the  situation  internally  with  considerable  apprehension.  The  events  of  June  30,  when  a  number  of  Storm  Troopers  were  shot  out  of  hand,  when  General  von  Schleicher  and  his  wife  were  assassinated,  and  an  unknown  number  of  persons  disposed  of,  have  left  a  very  sour  impression  in  Germany  as  to  the  future.  The  re  ception  accorded  to  the  Chancellor,  when  he  addressed  the  Reichstag  a  fortnight  after  those  events,  was  cool  in  the  extreme.  The  per  sonal  accounts  of  eye  witnesses  are  now  available  in  Australia,  and  confirm  in  every  detail  and  strengthen  the  observations  which  were  cabled  to  this  country  at  that  time.  The  position  has  been  summed  up  as  representing  the  end  of  Nazism  as  it  has  been  in  the  past,  and  the  beginning  of  its  end  altogether.  The  internal  position  in  Germany  is  of  the  first  importance,  not  only  to  Germany,  but  to  the  rest  of  the  world,  because,  whatever  happens  in  that  country  must  seriously  affect  affairs  in  other  parts  of  the  world,  particularly  the  present  stage  of  economic  recovery.  This  has  been  seen  in  Australia  by  the  fall  in  the  wool  market,  fol  lowing  upon  the  embargo  laid  by  Germany  upon  the  import  of  raw  material.  It  is  the  continued  uncertainty  as  to  what  will  eventuate  in  that  country  which  still  dominates  the  wool  market,  and  indeed,  all  other  markets  for  raw  materials.  It  is  not  until  Germany  becomes  stabilised  under  one  form  of  Government  or  another,  and  until  what  Shakespeare  calls  'the  alarums  and  excursions'  in  that  country  cease,  and  its  unhappy  people  can  settle  down  to  internal  peace  and  internal  development,  that  the  general  situation  can  right  itself.

heading: GERMAN PORTS.
article_text: GERMAN  PORTS.   The  total  amount  of  goods  handled  in  German  ports  during  1935  was  about  40  million  tons,  an  increase  of  1.78  million  tons  compared  witli  1934  and  8.61  mil  lion  tons  compared  witli  1933.  The  total  already  exceeds  that  of  1930  and  is  eciual  to  93.2  nor  cent,.   of  the  1929  figure.  Goods  pass  ing  between  the  ports  and  the  in  terior  have  increased  by  11.6  per  cent,  and  trade  with  foreign  coun  tries  by  10.4  per  cent.,  compared  with  1934.  Imports  from  abroad  fell  by  3.2  per  cent.  The  increase  in  goods  traffic  in  the  North  Sea  ports  only  amounted  to  1.4  per  cent.,  compared  with  16  per  cent,  in  the  Baltic  ports.  The  latter  's  share  of  the  total,  has  risen  from  24  per  cent,  to  32.5  per  cent,  dur  ing  the  past  year.

heading: GERMAN MUSIC.
article_text: GERMAN  MUSIC.   The  heritage  of  music  with  which  trie  German  nation  has  been  endowed  since  the  days  of  Bach  became  manifest  at  a  recital  of  recordings  before  members  of  the  German  sec-  tion  of  the  Modern  Language  Association  last   n  The  items  performed  covered  an  extensive   range  of  compositions,  including  songs  by  Mendelssohn,  Mozart,  and  Schubert.  Selections  from  German  folk-songs  created  a  happy  con-  trast,  and  served  to  Illustrate  the  diversified  musical  taste  of  the  nation.  Several  recita-  tions  from  the  works  of  Oocthe  and  Schiller,  ti,-  famous  German  poets,  were  also  repro-  duced,  and  added  to  the  variety  of  the  pro-  gramme,  which  was  under  the  joint  direction  of  the  president  of  the  section,  Mr.  J.  G.  Belschner,  and  the  secretary,  Mr.  V.  O.   Simon.

heading: GERMAN COURTSHIP.
article_text: GERMAN  COURTSHIP.   Courtship  in  Germany  is  a  very  business-like  affair.  All  the  love-  making  is  done  in  public.  Even  a  hichlv-born  en  traced  counle  walk   about  arm-in-arm  or  hand-in-hand.  They  embrace  in  public,  he  sits  with  his  arm  round  her  waist  at  dinner,  and  everyone  encourages  such  ver-  flowing  evidences  of  affection.  The  German,  however,  who  made  love  so  madly  before  marriage  allows  his  ardour  to  cool  after  a  few  years  of  wedded  life  are  passed.  Army  officers  are  regarded  as  ideal  husbands-for  well-to-do  girls,  but  the  father-in-law  generally  has  to  pay  the  soldier's  debts.  A  youth  may  be  only  a  penniless  lieutenant,  with  nothing  to  recommend  him  but  his  debts  and  his  uniform;  but,  provided  he  comes  of  a  good  family,  he  can  propose  for  any  daughter,  no  matter  how  well-to-  do  or  exalted  a  personage  her  father  'may  be.  Herr  Papa  pays  the  lieu  tenant's  debts  and  provides  everything  for  the  household.  The  girl  is  probably  already  pos  sessed  of  some  furniture  and  much  household  linen,  as  in  many  families  these  goods  and  chattels  arc  accumu  lated  for  daughters  from  the  day  of  their  birth.  They  arc  given  as  birth  day  and  Christmas  presents,  as  the  chief  object  kept  in  view  during  a  girl's  earlier  life  is  matrimony.
snippet: Courtship in Germany is a very business-like affair. All the love- making is done in public. Even a highly-born en traced couple walk

heading: German Defeat.
article_text: German  Defeat.   THE  former  Crown  Prince  Rupprecht  of  Bavaria,  commander  of  the  German  sixth  army  on  the  Western  Front,  has  recently  published,  in  some-   what  condensed  form,  his  wartime  diary.  Bupprecht  was  a  competent  soldier,  not  a  merely  decorative  army  chief  like  the  Crown  Prince  of  Prussia,  writes  a  Berlin  correspondent.  He  exercised  actual  command,  and  was  re  garded  with  respect  by  the  real  di  rectors  of  German  operations,  the  men  In  control  of  the  General  Staff,  and  the  High  Command.  He  also  possessed  an  independence  of  judgment  which  enabled  him  to  see  the  errors  committed  by  his  superiors  and  to  sense  the  German  military  failure  at  a  time  when  the  highest  military  authorities  were  still  deceiv  ing  the  public  with  predictions  of  vic  ton  and  a  profitable  peace.  An  article  in  the  "Vossische  Zeitung"  notes  and  comments  on  some  of  the  diary's  more  striking  entries.  It  says:  '"More  than  a  year  ahead  I  saw  coming  everything  that  did  come/  he  wrote  on  November  1,  1018,  to  his  father,  to  whom  during  the  war  he  had  imparted  his  hopes  and  cares  in  a  long  series  of  very  detailed  letters.  He  recognised  the  causes  of  the  break  down—the  declining  strength  of  an  overtaxed  and  decimated  army,  and  the  numerical  superiority  of  the  Allies,  due  to  decisive  American  reinforce  ments.  In  these  frank  letters-to  his  father  there  is  no  talk  of  a  'stab  in  the  back.'  "On  the  contrary.  The  bow  was  bent  so  far  that  it  finally  broke/  he  wrote  on  September  30.  1918.  Already,  on  June  1.  1918,  when  Ludendorff  stlH  hoped  to  break  through  the  French  front  with  his  offensive,  the  Crown  Prince  advised  peace  in  a  report  to  Chancellor  Hertling:  Now  we  have  trumps  in  our  hand—later  we  -shall  hare  none.'  "He  was  not  deceived  by  the  initial  successes  of  the  Boissons-Rheinvs  of  fensive  in  July,  1918:  'In  the  horn*  Press  these  last  few  days  the  battle*  near  Rheims  and  Boiasons  are  pictured  as  great  German  successes,  on  the  of  fensive  and  on  the  defensive.  I  iind  such  deception  of  public  opinion  in  excusable/  "On  September  4  he  saw  thai  only  an  immediate  peace  proposal  could  stave  off  the  catastrophe.  Re  wrote:  'The  general  situation  Is  more  critical  than  ever.  The  battalions  of  the  regi  ments  coming  out  of  battle  often  num  ber  between  40  and  4O?  men.  It  is  also  to  be  feared  that  under  some  cir  cumstances  the  enemy  may  succeed  within  a  few  days  in  breaking  thepugh  our  front.  An  immediate  peace  pro  posal—even  with  great  sacrifices—is  urgently  required/  "On  September  30  he  saw  that  all  was  lost,  although,  as  he  stated  out,  'every  one  who  expresses  hia  opinion  is  regarded  as  a  slacker  and  pessimist  a  weakling,  and  an  inferior  person/  He  said:  ~  •  .  "  "What  I  have  long  feared  has  hap  pened  sooner  than  I  expected—the  de  cisive  defeat.  In  two  days  we  have  lost  800  guns,  and  the  troops  have  no  more  power  of  resistance.  They  arc  tired  out.  and  no  longer  a  match  for  the  enemy's  superior  forces.  AiscT  things  are  going  badly  on  the  ether  fronts,  and  we  must  be  prepared  for  the  very  worst.  It  is  urgently  necessary  to  con  clude  peace  at  any  price,  for  we  are  as  good  as  defenceless/  "  The  Crown  Prlace  also  criticises  both  the  Weimar  and  fee  Bismarckian  con  stitutions  for  giving  too  much  power  to  Prussia.  He  says  on  this  point:  •*With  all  the  North's  services  it  cannot  be  denied  that  under  its  polit  ical  leaderahin  Germany  suffered  the  greatest  political  catastrophe  in  her  history."

heading: GERMAN REFUGEES
article_text: GERMAN  REFUGEES   The  German  freighter,  Lahn,  which  arrived  at  Sydney  to-day  from  Antwerp,  brought  13  passengers.  All  were  Jews,  and  they  refused  to  state  their  occupations  or  to  say  what  they  intended  doing  in  Australia,  fearing  that  their  relatives  in  Ger  many  would  be  harmed.

heading: GERMAN COURTESY.
article_text: GERMAN  COURTESY.   A  motorist  who  has  just  returned  from  a.  holiday;  in  Germany,  was  particularly  impressed  by  the  courtesy  extended  to  him  throughout  his  tour.  One  thing  which  he  noticed  particularly  was  the  ready  assistance  forthcoming  from  passers-by,  particularly  in  larger  towns  and  cities.  On  more  than  one  occasion,  he  tells  us,  no  sooner  had  he  pulled  up  to  take  stock  of  his  surroundings  than  ą  passer-by,  noticing  the  foreign  registration  of  the  can  came  up  to  enquire  whether  he  couM  be  of  any  assistance  to  guide  the  traveller  to  his  destination.  German  frontier  authorities  hand  the  visiting  motorist,  a  booklet  giving  full  illu-.  strated  details  of  the  German  traffic  signs  and  a  list  of  the  principal  rules  of  the  road,  the  latter  being  printed  in  German,  French  and  English.

heading: GERMAN BARTER.
article_text: GERMAN  BARTER.   The  German  barter  system  should  have  a  solid  check  in  the  guarantees  given  to  European  countries  by  England  and  France.  Direct  barter  of  certain  definite  bulk  lines  needed  for  immediate  consumption  in  the  countries  concerned  in  the  interchange  may  prove  practical*  but  the  German  policy  is  loaded  against  the  buyer  of  ^ei'man  goods.  .  •  In  many  instances  where  payment  y  Germany  has  been  by  various  lines,  the  quality,  modernity  and  other  features  of  the  articles  have  been  found  sadly  wanting  and  in  South  America  and  Eastern  Europe,  the  sharp  practices  of  German  exporters  have  led'to  the  cancellation  of  the  agreements.  There  u,  however,  a  more  serious  factor  for  consideration.  In  most  instances  German  purchases  are  of  primary  products.  Having  secured  supplies  of  such  goods  the  German  authorities  instead,  of  taking  the  goods  into  home  consumption,  have  thrown  them  on  to.certain  markets  points,  evidently  with  the  double  object  of  breaking  the  market  standard  and  at  the  same  time  securing  forr  eign  credits.  This  has  been  done  repeatedly  with  butter  purchased  from  neighboring  countries  and  then  resold  to  their  detriment.  It  could  easily  be  the  same  with  wool,  and  in  this  direction  South  African  woolgrowers  are  becoming  nervous  as  to  the  real  merit  of  the  agreement  which  gives  Germany  wool  at  a  world  price,  and  helps  to  destroy  other  purchasers  trading  power  ,by  the  distribution  of  bartered  manufactured  goods  in  which  the  political  aims  of  the  Nazi  authorities  have   jnore  consideration  than  the  welfare  •  ^  concerned  in  production.  The  entry  of  Dictatorism  into  marketing,  a  natural  sequence  to  Govern  ment  interference  in  trade  and  production,  has  had  startling  lessons.  German  manipulation  of  produce  and  other  like  markets  has  been  disastrous,  but  how  much  heavy  fluctuaitons  in  stocks  and  bonds  have  been  due  to  premeditated  war  scares,  will  make  a  pretty  story  of  gangsterism  cn  a  national  scale  when  the  full  hiscriminality  against  suppliers  of  goods  tory  of  the  last  few  years  is  revealed.  A  nation  without  character  in  its  national  transactions  with  other  coun  tries,  a  country  whose  currency  has  been  manipulated  to  a  last  degree  of  j  and  whose  history  is  a  continuous  one  of  broken  faith,  cannot  be  accepted  without  some  solid  proofs  of  return  to  honesty  and  good  faith.  Barter  or  dealings  with  Germany  under  present  conditions  is  only  playing  with  fire  and  invitation  for  a  burning.

heading: GERMAN ELECTIONS.
article_text: GERMAN  ELECTIONS.   Monday's  general  election  to  the  Reichstag  has  merely  perpetuated  the  deadlock  which  existed  in  the  late  House,  which  was  elected  on  July  3:1.  The  Government  of  Captain  von  Fapen,  which  was  appointed  without  reference  to  Parliamentary  party  sftrength  by  President  von  Hindenburg  after  the  fall  of  Dr.  Bruening  early  in  the  year,  and  which  exercised  a  virtual  dictatorship  by  authority  of  the  President  and  the  power  of  the  Federal  army,  is  still  faced  with  a  tremendous  hostile  majority.  Though  its  supporters  slightly  increased  theii  strength  it  is  computed,  on  the  official   provisional  returns  of  Monday's  poll  that  it  can  muster  only  74  votes  against  507  in  the  new  House  of  581  members.  In  view  of  the  continuance  of  the  deadlock,  which  was  generally  expected,  the  von  Papen  Government  will  continue  in  power.
snippet: Monday’s general election to the Reichstag has merely perpetuated the deadlock which existed in the late House, which was elected on July 31.

heading: GERMAN DEMOCRACY
article_text: GERMAN  DEMOCRACY   ANYTHING  like  an'intelligent   criticism  ;  of  the  speech  of  Herr  Hitler  is  impossible  on  a  first  reading,  and  without  some  guidance  of  opinion  from  those;  who  are  more  closely  in  touch  with  conditions.  Just  as  a  first  thought,  we  are  inclined  to  say  that  there  is  much  fuss  and  fury,  and  very  little  of  solid  fact  or  real-  ity.  '  Throughout  the  speech  we  seem  to  hear  the  clashing  of  arms,  but  with  a  mediaeval  flavour,  as  though  some  ancient  chivalry  under  the  stress  of  emotion  were   banging  swords  and  maces  against  shields  for'the  especial  purpose  of  terrifying  their  enemies.  But  the  initial  remarks  regarding  German  democracy  sound  (strangely  in  Australian  ears.  Herr  Hitler  be-  gan  by  declaring  that  Germany  has  a  democratic  constitution,   which  is  responsible  to  the  people  through  a  single  Deputy,  elected  by  the  votes  of  the  people.  This  indi  vidual  is  expected  to.  harmon-  ise  his  actions  with  his  conscience   to  God,  and  his  duty  to  the  people   he  serves.  We  think  that  no  one   in  this  period  of.  experience  will  doubt  the  sincerity  of  Herr  Hitler  nor  the  reality  of  his  belief  in  his  mission.  But  that  very  sincerity  makes  him  the  more  dangerous.  Democracy  as  represented  by  the  consolidation  of  full  power  of.  Government  in  one  man,  with-an  appointed  bureaucracy  to  carry  out  his  orders,  does  not  seem  to  fit  in  with  any  ideas  gathered  either  from  the  past  or  the  pre-  sent.  And!  a  democrat  who  is  an  autocrat,  and  who  while  passion-  ately  declaring  the  futility  of  war,  organises  his  people  on  a  war  basis,  must  be  regarded  as  a  men-  ace.  Perhaps  Herr  Hitler's  de-  finition^  German  democracy  may  stimulate  thoughtful  people  in  other  countries  to  consider  whether,  in  practice,  there  is  such  a  thing.

heading: GERMAN PROGRAMMES.
article_text: GERMAN  PROGRAMMES.   Official  figures  analysing  the  contents  of  the  German  programmes  during  the  first  quarter  of  1934  have  been  published.  The  nercentace  of  nrotrramme  time  devoted  to   music  has  increased  to  bO.7  per  cent,  com  pared  with  55.5  per  cent  during  the  same  period  of  last  year.  The  time  occupied  by  talks,  on  the  other  hand,  has  fallen  from  14  per  cent  in  the  first  quarter  of  1933  to  9  per  cent  for  1934.  Political  reports  and  news,  etc.,  are  practically  the  same  at  10.8  per  cent.  The  fact  that  the  total  num  ber  of  broadcasting  hours  has  increased  from  12.000  during  the  first  three  months  of  1933  to  14,500  during  the  same  period  of  this  year  is  owing  to  the  greater  activi  ties  of  the  German  short-wave  station.  Only  -2.9  per  cent  of  the  programme  hours,  was  devoted  to  outside  broadcasts.-  Foreign  countries  contributed  0.1  per  cent.  r

heading: German Gluttons.
article_text: German  Gluttons.   MUNICH,  July  17.-Dr.  Wirz,  a  Nazi  ¡  health  expert,  said  in  the  course  of  a  j  speech  here  today  that  food  gluttons  in  ,  Germany  were  guilty  of  "high  treason."  ,   Dr.  Wirz  said  the  consumption  of  meat  ]  had  increased  400  per  cent  and  the  con-  sumption  of  butter  100  per  cent  since  1933,  and  this  was  responsible  for  the  existing  shortage.  Apart  from  health  deterioration  any  German  immoderately  consuming  meats  and  fats  endangered  the  nutritive  independence  of  the  nation  and  thus  attacked  its  political  security.  Therefore  he  was  guilty  of  high  trea-   son.
snippet: MUNICH, July 17.—Dr. Wirz, a Nazi health expert, said in the course of a speech here today that food gluttons in Germany were guilty of "high treason."

article_text: German  Repayment  A  Basle  message  says  that  the  Bank  of  International'  Settlements  an  nounces  that  Germany  has  repaid  £2,000,000  as  the  required  five  per  cent.  of  her  credit.  The  remaining  £18,000,000  is  renewed  for  three  months.

heading: GERMAN MINES
article_text: GERMAN  MINES  GERMANY'S  RUTHLESS  and  in  discriminate  use  of  mines  is  plainly  intended  to  frighten  all  ship  ping  away  from  Britain.  Since  she  has  no  friends  to  lose  she  has  thrown  all  the  laws  of  warfare  overboard  and  is  prepared  to  sink  the  ships  of  any  nation  in  a  desperate  attempt  to  blockade  Britain  as  she  herself  is  blockaded.  It  is  a  campaign  of  ter  rorism  that  will  serve  only  to  hasten  the  alignment  of  nations  in  active  opposition  to  Germany  in  this  war.  Apart  from  the  way  in  which  the  mines  are  being  used,  the  terrific  explosive  content  of  some  of  them  is  proof  of  Germany's  hope  of  in  timidating  all  shipping  movement  in  English  waters.  The  charges  are  far  stronger  than  necessary  merely  to  sink  a  ship.  The  vessels  that  strike  them  are  blown  almost  to  pieces,  making  heavy  loss  of  civilian  life  in  evitable.  The  sinking  of  the  Japanese  liner,  Terekuni  Maru,  will  cause  great  anger  and  perturbation  in  Japan,  and  may  have  a  profound  effect  upon  Japanese  foreign  policy  at  a  time  when  Nippon's  international  rela  tions  are  in  a  state  of  flux.  It  will  be  useless  for  Germany  to  blame  Mr.  Winston  Churchill  for  the  mining  of  this  vessel.  Surprisingly  enough,  the  Nazis  have  now  admitted  that  their  mines  have  been  responsible  for  the  loss  of  the  neutral  vessels  sunk  dur  ing  the  last  few  days.  "Germany  re  grets  it  if  the  results  are  rather  sad  for  neutrals,  but  can  do  nothing  about  it,"  said  a  broadcast  from  Hamburg.  Perhaps  she  would  not  have  been  so  frank  had  she  known  that  within  a  few  hours  a  crack  Jap  anese  liner  was  to  be  sent  to  the  bottom  of  the  sea  by  her  agency.  Japan  will  consider  this  disaster  in  conjunction  with  the  report  that  Germany  has  bought  from  Russia  twenty  submarines  for  operations  in  the  Far  East  and  the  Indian  Ocpan.  The  risk  of  total  war  being  extended  by  Germany  to  these  seas  cannot  be  dismissed.  So  far  as  Britain  is  con  cerned,  it  is  extremely  unlikely  that  the  new  German  frightfulness  will  be  successful  in  cutting  her  off  from  the  world  and  starving  her  into  submis  sion.  The  mine  menace  was  dealt  with  in  the  last  war,  and  there  is  no  reason  to  fear  that  this  success  will  not  be  repeated.

heading: German Warships.
article_text: German  Warships.   Germany  is  clearly  determined  to  perpetuate  in  lier  Relchsmarine  the  best  traditions  of  the  former  Imper  ial  Navy  (writes  "Peterborough"  in  the  London  "Daily  Telegrfljpli")   Her  second  pocket  battleship,  which  was  commissioned  recently,  is  named  after  Admiral  Scheer,  who  so  ably  commanded  the  Fleet  at  Jutland.  The  third  ship  of  this  type,  now  completing,  bears  the  name  of  Admiral  Graf  von  Spee,  who  went  down  with  his  nagship  Scharnhorst,  at  the  Falklands.  The  fourth  unit,  shortly  to  be  laid  down,  is  expected  to  commemorate  Admir  al  von  Hipper  who  won  renown  by  his  gallant  leadership  of  the  Ger  man  battle  cruisers  at  Jutland.

article_text: GERMAN  POLITICS   The  unhappy  political  .situation  in  Clormany,  following  the  recent  elec  tions,  was  .strongly  reflected  in  the  I'iot.s  that  marked  the  opening  of  the  Reichstag.  It  is  not  surprising  that  President  Hindenburgh  should  be  credited  with  the  intention  of  appoint  ing1  a  Cabinet  or  Directorate  consisting  of  non-political  elements.  It  is  an  im  pressive  paradox  that  the  present  posi  tion  in  Germany  lias  been  largely  brought  about  by  the  very  efiiciency  imon  which  she  based  her  dramatic   tniflo  recovery  after  the  war.   —Murwil-  I   lumbah  "Daily."

heading: German Universities
article_text: German  Universities   Sir,  -  Would  you  permit  me  to  make  comment  on  Sir  James  Barrett's  letter,  which  appeared  in  Saturday's  magazine  section  under  the  heading  "German  Uni-  versities."  The  writer  states  that  2,000  non-Aryans  and  others  have  been  dis-  missed  from'the  German  universities  be-  cause  their  outlook  did  not  commend  Itself  to  the  German  Government,  and  hopes  this  is  due  only  to  a  passing  emotional  phase.  To  this  I  would  like  to  add  that  not  only  the  universities,  but  the  Press,  cinema,  theatre,  musical  world,  publishing  houses,  art  world,  schools,  and  professions  -in  short,  all  spheres  which  are  able  to  influence  human  thought  in  a  large  way  -have  been  relieved  of  the  influence  of  people  who  were  known  to  have  used  their  positions  to  spread  the  communistic  ideol-  ogy  by  methods  that  were  so  ably  exposed  in  a  series  of  articles  in  your  paper  quite  recently.  This  was  done  in  order  that  Ger-  man  culture  would  be  able  to  advance  within  the  framework  and  in  the  direction  laid  down  by  Goethe,  Schiller,  Lessing,  &c.,  whom  Sir  James  Barrett  mentions  so  wistfully.  The  German  Government  holds  that  a  people's  culture  derives  its  direc-  tion  from  its  past,  and  can  only  develop  in  the  direction  laid  down  by  that  past;  and  that  alien  influences  can  only  destroy   it.   -  Yours,  &c,  F.  A.  BUETTNER.   South  Yarra,  June  26.

heading: German Figures
article_text: German  Figures  The  figures  for  the  so-called  Ger  man  election  are  surely  astounding.  Allowing  for  the  possibility  that  the  Nazi  appeal  caught  the  imagination  of  the  German  people  to  a  much  greater  extent  than  on  the  occasion  of  the  election  for  the  Roichstag  in  March  last,  it  is  impossible  to  accept  the  suggestion  contained  in  the  figures  that  the  people,  forgetful  of  former  divisions,  have  pooled  their  strength  for  the  purpose  of  supporting  Herr  Hitler  and  his  friends.  The  more  rea  sonable.  view  is  that.  though  the  appeal  to  unity  sounded  emotional  depths  to  a  greater  extent  than  for  merly,  fear  operated  to  prevent  a  true  expression  of  opinion.  For  the  Nazis  are  known  In  their  own  country  as  the  upholders  of  force.  and  of  any  method  to  secure  what  they  regard  as  the  welfare  of  the  State.  Taking  the  referendum.  the  question  was-"Do  "you,  German  man,  and  you,  German  "woman,  approve  of  the  policy  of  your  "Government?  Are  you  ready  to  ye  "cognise  it  as  the  expression  of  your  "own  views,  and  will  you  solemnly  "pledge  yourself  to  it?"  The  question  is  important  in  considering  the  figures,  for  only  2.055,000  voted  in  the  nega  tive  compared  with  43,464,000  in  the  affirmative.  If  the  vote  is  a  true  reflex  of  opinion,  the  world  is  told  that  7.000,000  Social  Democrats  and  4.000,000  Communists  who  were  against  the  Nazis  last  March  have  been.  converted  by  a  brutal  terrorism  into  enthusiastic  admiration  for  the  Nazi  regime.  The  relatives  and  friends  of  thousands  of  men  who  have  become  outcasts.  and  thousands  of  others  who  have  been  thrown  into  concentration  camps,  are  so  grateful  to  the  Government  that  they  went  en  thuslastically  to  the  polls  to  testify  their  opinions.  It  is  certainly  difficult  to  believe.  However.  Hitler  has  secur  ed  his  triumph.  Enthusiasm  and  fear  combined  to  produce  acceptable  effects,  and  he  may  talk  before  the  world  as  the  leader  of  a  united  people  lifted  up  by  noble  purposes.

A  ban  which  was  placed  on  them  carlyi  in  the  war  is  to  be  lifted. heading: GERMAN INNOVATIONS.
article_text: GERMAN  INNOVATIONS.   Germany,  is  trying  to  persuade  girls  to  grow  plaits  in  order  to  help  the  ribbon  trade.  Nearly  a  thousand  schools  for  girls  are  displaying  pos  ters  of  young  Gretchens  with  long  plaits  and  big  bows  of  ribbon  most  decoratively  arranged.  Another  Nazi  Idea  is  the  introduction  of  Rugby  foot  -   ball  to  German  boys,  and  a  tar  reaching  organisation  has  been  form  ?  ed  to  make  the  game  popular.  It  is  of  interest  to  know  why  Rugby  is  thus  fostered.  One  German  writer  avows  tne  reason  to  be  that  it  encourages  the  fighting  spirit.  It  is  true  thar,  Rugger  may  be  played  roughly,  but  it  is  a  true  sport,  and  if  played  in  a  sportsmanlike  way  fosters  much  more  than  the  desire  to  fight.  British  and  German  boys  will  probably  scon  be  plnying  it  together  in  friendly  rivalry.

article_text: GERMAN  POLITICS.   The  latest  move  of  Herr  Hitler  sug  gests  an  impending  coup  d'etat  in  the  free  city  of  Danzig.  He  has  given  the  Nazi  leader  in  Danzig  full  powers  to  ensure  the  immediate  reconstruction  of  the  Senate  there. heading: GERMAN CREDITS.
article_text: GERMAN  CREDITS.   Sir,  —  Under  date  of  12/2/37,  writing  from  Hobart,  Tasmania,  and  duly  pub  lished  in  the  "Daily  Examiner,"  Mr.  William  Ager  states.—  It  is  reported  that  Germany  has  a  rlpht.  nf  £90(100  000  nf  loan  at  short  call.   mostly  on  England,  and  .which  she  states  she  is  unable  to  pay.  It  is  also-  rumored  that  efforts  are  being  made  to  make  the  United  States  receptive  towards  another  loan  to  Ger  many,  such  loan  to  be  made  jointly  by  British,  French,  and  United  States  in  terests.  It  must  be  clearly,  understood  that  when  a  nation  secures  a  loan  from  another  nation  no  money  is  inter  changed.  Goods  or  materials  are  taken  to  the  amount  of  the  credits  extended.  :  Since  1918  credits  have  been  extend  ed  to  Germany  through  the  control  re  serve  franking  system  in  America  and  England,  and  Germany  as  a  conse  quence  has  become  so  completely  or  ganised  in  air,  field  and  naval  arma  ments  that  she  is  able  to  ignore  the  League  of  Nations,  defy  the  world  and  .hop  over  and  win  unopposed  conquests,  and  the  prevaricating,  subtle,  under  mining  diplomacy  stills  prevails  to  draw  further  goods  and  materials  to  the  strorighold.  Blatantly  denying  the  responsibility  for  the  last  war,  she  may  yet  blame  Britain  for  the  next  be  cause  the  world  is  not  willing  to  hand  over  mandated  territories  upon  demand.  It  must  be  clearly  ,  understood  that  the  world  is  not  dealing  with  German  people,  who  are  a  very  fine  race.  A  gang  of  fiends  who  are  organising  world  wide  mass  murder,  hide  behind  all  this  vast  camouflage  and  the  German  people  are  .  hungry  because  their  resources,  energy  and  hundreds  of  millions  Of  pounds  of  their  wealth  are  absorbed  annually  in  the  maintenance  and  fur  ther  development  of  the  mighty  war  organisation.  The  bluff  about  being  unable  to  pay  has  continued  all  too  long.  The  people  of  the  world  in  general,  and  Great  Bri  tain  in  particular,  should  rub  their  sleepy  eyes  and  realise  what  is  hap  pening  by  the  international  money  sys  tem  controlling  and  extending  credits.  When  Great  Britain  needs  armaments  for  defence,  made  necessary  by  such  gigantic  and,  advanced  preparations  in  Germany,  she  is  told  by  the  same  inter  national  money  monopoly  that  she  must  provide  her  defences  from  taxation.  It  is  to  be  regretted  that  there  is  an  absence  of  such  writers  on  national  and  international  affairs.  In  substantiation  of  Mr.  Ager's  con  tribution,  I  quote  a  broadcast  speeclFby  Dr.  Goddard  on  Sunday  night,  February  14,  on  international  affairs  from  2BL  recorded  in  "The  Book  of  Time."  Per  chance  many  listeners  are  aware  that  Dr.  Goddard  is  an  authority  on  inter  national  affairs.  He  said:  Germany  in  her  race  for  armaments  is  depriving  every  individual  population  of  £160  of  food  yearly.  -From  time  to  time  the  cables  flash  across  the  world  some  startling  arith  metic,  but  unfortunately  the  country  press  only  receives  a  brevis  .  account  -in  a  condensed  or  mutilated  'form.  Since   1914  to  1927  it  has  been  my  hobby  to  devote  my  leisure  to  national  and  in  ternational  affairs  published  monthly  in  the  magazine  "Life."  Some  newspaper  writers,  -of  course,  if  only  by  force,  of  habit,  reflect  and  exaggerate  the  mood  ;  of  the  moment,  and  they  change  with  the  mood.  They  are  not  so  closely  in  touch  with  actual  facts.  .DISTRACTED  GERMANY.  Germany,  to  the  hasty  observer,  might  well  seem  to  be  on  the  point  of  bank  ruptcy.  In  1923  Sir  Phillip  Gibbs,  thei  noted  war  correspondent,  visited  .  Ger-  1  many,  and  gave  a  graphic  story  of  what:  he  saw  there.  He  said,  however,  that  with  the  mark  at  5uo,000,000  to  the  Eng  lish  pound  note  there  was  still  no  out  ward  sign  of  poverty  or  rum  in  Ger  many."  He  could  not  make  head  or  cail  of  this  wild  melodrama  of  paper  money  which,  fell  .In  value  by  tens:,  of  millions  between  the  "soup  and  the  xoffee  of  his  midday  meal.  It  seemed  to  make  "no  difference  "  tOtKe  people.  They  still  thronged  the  restaurants  and  cabarets  and  though  .prices  rose.  auto  matically  as  the  exchange  falls,  thev  .eemed  to  get  enough  of  this  f\ntastic  currency  to  pay  f  0  c.  their  pleasure  as  well  as  their  necessity.  "But,"  he  added,  "this  is  the  way  in  which  mod  ern  civilisation  '  masks  for  a  time  the  decay  and  the  disease  which  are  eating  at  its  vitals  like  a  spreading  cancer."  Even  to  the  cool  Australian  mind  looking  across  the  sea  at  the  distrac  tions  and  tumult  of  what  we  call  "Ger  many,"  it  seems  .that.it  offers  a  spec  tacle  of  ruin  such  as  Europe  has  not  seen  since  the  Forty  Years'  "Vvar.  Yet  the  ruin  is  not  brought  on  Germany  by   the  sword  of  its  enemies,  but  by  the  insane  policy  of  its  own  rulers.  They  were  too  proud  to  accept  defeat,  and  have  tried  to  evade;  its  just  conse  quences.  The  German  currency  has  been  deliberately  ruined—  and  ruined  on  a  scale  unknown;.in  history—  as  part  of  the  plan  to  make  the  payment  of  the  reparations  for  the  wrongs  done  to  the  nations  it  attacked.  We  have  but  to  contrast  how  Germany  treated  France  in  1870.  For  six  months'  war  she  exacted  a  fine  of  £200,000,000  —  and  Alsace-Lorraine!  And  her  troops  were  quartered  on  France  -till  this  penalty  was  paid.  .Or  we  have  but  to  contrast  the  policy  since  defeat  adopted  by  Austria  with  that  of  Germany  to  realise  that  Germany  has.  brought'  upon  itself  the  suffering  which  now  almost  theatens  it  with  destruction.  Austria  accepted  its  defeat,  and  has  honestly  paid,  as  far  as  possible  the  price  of  defeat!  As  a  result,  it  has  the  sympathy  and  help  of  Europe,  and  is  back  towards  prosper  ity.  It  is  cruel,  perhaps,  to  say  that  '  Germany  has  tried  to  cheat  its  creditors,  but  has  it  honestly  tried'  to  pay  them?  THE  DANCE  OF  THE  GERMAN  MARK.  Only  a  mathematician  accustomed  to  deal  with  what-  may  be  called  astrono  mical  magnitudes  can  keep  touch  with  the  performances  of  the  German  mark;  but  a  record  of  its  gyrations  during,  say,  a  single  fortnight,  may  be  attempt  ed.  The  week  before  the  issue  of  the  Baldwin-Curzon  note,  the  German  mark  was  rated  at  4,000,000  to  the  dollar,  a'rid  under  the  influence  of  the  British  letter   it  went  up  a  few  points  and  reached  2.500,000  to  the  dollar.  Then  came  the  blast  of  Poincai-e's  reply,  with  its  twin  document  from  Brussels,  and  the  mark  tumbled  down  with  meteoric  speed  till  it  touched  about  7,000,000;:  and  then  8,000,000  to  the  dollar.  On.:  September  5,  1923,  it  had  gone  almost  completely  out  of  sight,  as  it  descended  to  20,000,000  to  the  dollar,  and  continued  its  downward  flight  till  it  actually  reached  44,000,000  to  the  dollar.  The  mark,  it  must  be  remembered,  .before  the  Great  War,  was  equal  in  I  value  to  the  British  shilling;  at  the  point  reached  it  was  equal  to  a  forty-  millionth  part  of  a  dollar,  a  value  which  only  a  microscope  of  the  highest  magni  fying  power  could  do  so  much  as  see.  It  was  expected  then  to  fall  tc  100,  LOU,  000  to  the  dollar",  which  is  about  zero,  and  at  that  stage  "not  only  cities,  towns  and  Villages,  but  State  railways,  banks,  manufacturing  co-operations,  business  houses  and  even  .  individuals  have  been  printing  and  issuing  their  own  flat  money  during  tnc  I  shortage."  Now,  how  can  civilised  existence  continue  under  such  con  ditions?  And  since  then  the  mark  has  fallen  to  yet  lower  depths!—  I  am,  etc.,   PETER  KNIGHT.  -
